did.unittitle: Library Company of Philadelphia conservation records

bioghist.p: The Library Company of Philadelphia is an independent research library concentrating on American society and culture from the 17th through 19th centuries. It was founded in 1731 by Benjamin Franklin as a subscription library supported by its shareholders, as it is to this day. Free and open to the public, the Library Company houses an extensive non-circulating collection of rare books, manuscripts, broadsides, ephemera, and works of art.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of documents related to several conservation projects, including the 1992-1993 restoration of the Lazzarini statue of Benjamin Franklin and assessment of paintings owned by the Library Company performed between 1988 and 1991. Materials related to the restoration of the Franklin statue include an examination report and treatment recommendations, slides, photographs, and negatives of the project, and samples of marble from the statue. The collection also includes a small batch of materials related to the sale of paintings, furniture, and objects.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
